name: carex grayi
description:
Carex grayi is an ornamental sedge that grows in moist
environments as slowly spreading clumps. It is an uncommon sedge because it
thrives in both woodlands and wetlands, as well as being a great choice for
planting along streams. Here at Prairie Moon, this species has thrived in rain
gardens that are in full sun and full shade. Gray sedge will also tolerate
occasional flooding. 
Like many sedge species, its most attractive (and most
photographed) phase is during its mid-summer fruiting period. The star-like
flower makes Gray sedge an attractive addition to fresh or dried arrangements. Some
say the flower looks more like a medieval weapon than a star, and the sedge is
sometimes called Mace Sedge.
The wind-pollinated flowers of Carex species attract few
insects but various butterfly larvae will eat the foliage including the Eyed
Brown Butterfly and the Appalachian Brown Butterfly. The seeds of sedges are food sources for many kinds of
birds and mammals, including game birds, song birds, muskrat, and white-tailed
deer.
features: Deer Resistant (Our experiences here in the Upper Midwest may vary in other regions; deer can respond differently to local conditions or seasonal variations.)
